review.title: Computational Algorithms Based on the Paninian System to Process Euphonic Conjunctions for Word Searches
review.abstract: Searching for words in Sanskrit E-text is a problem that is accompanied by complexities introduced by features of Sanskrit such as euphonic conjunctions or sandhis. A word could occur in an E-text in a transformed form owing to the operation of rules of sandhi. Simple word search would not yield these transformed forms of the word. Further, there is no search engine in the literature that can comprehensively search for words in Sanskrit E-texts taking euphonic conjunctions into account. This work presents an optimal binary representational schema for letters of the Sanskrit alphabet along with algorithms to efficiently process the sandhi rules of Sanskrit grammar. The work further presents an algorithm that uses the sandhi processing algorithm to perform a comprehensive word search on E-text.

sections.heading: A. Language Representation
sections.text: The Unicode hexadecimal range 0900 - 097F is used to render Sanskrit letters in Devanāgarī font. Characters used to render Sanskrit letters in English font are found in the Unicode ranges Basic Latin (0000-007F), Latin-1 Supplement (0080-00FF), Latin Extended-A (0100-017F) and Latin Extended Additional (1E00 - 1EFF). The Latin character set was used in this thesis to render Sanskrit letters as e-text. Therefore, the scheme presented and the algorithms do not use Devanāgarī font. To use the algorithms for text in Devanāgarī font, the text must first be converted to Latin text.

sections.heading: A. The Approach
sections.text: The present work is based on earlier work by the authors, in which Pāṇini's rules are codified in a novel way by binary representations. [4] The unique data representation conceived by the authors has been further refined in this work, and consonant-based, visarga-based Sandhi rules as well as some specific Sandhi rules have been incorporated into this work. Rule representation has been simplified to minimal binary set-unset operations. Furthermore, the Sūtra order has been carried out after gaining a thorough understanding of the workings of Pāṇini's sandhi-related aphorisms. As such, this work represents a significant extension, refinement and completion of the earlier work of the authors. Furthermore, it provides a clear understanding of the rules for Sandhi laid down by Pāṇini in a comprehensive and simplified way that has not previously been found in the literature.
